newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Oct 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Oct 23.

text.p: The following is a summary of major South Korean political stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not gaurantee their accuracy. Telephone: (822) 727-5650. Fax: (822) 727-5666.
- Large corporations are being pressed to retrench their investments next year in the wake of export downturns and the economy's slowdown. Worsening employment conditions look inevitable.

- Former Defense Minister Lee's bond accounts are being tracked as part of an investigation into arms contract graft charges. Daewoo Group's executive Yoon Young-suk has also been summoned by prosecution due to the bribery scandal. Yoon claims Daewoo is being framed by the Korean-American arms dealer who first disclosed former defense chief Lee's involvement in the scandal.
- South Korea has to maintain its superiority in strength over North Korea in order to deter war, according to ruling party chirman Lee Hong-koo.
- Government, ruling party agree on fair trade law amendment bill, drastically easing regulations governing large conglomerates.

- State prosecutors, probing an alleged bribery scandal involving former defense minister Lee Yang-ho, questioned Daewoo Group chairman, Yoon Young-suk, to determine whether a Daewoo subsidiary gave bribes to Lee in return for a lecense to take part in an arms buildup programme.
- A senior Daewoo executive admitted that Daewoo officials gave 300 million won to an arms dealer in 1995 in hopes of winning an arms deal. But he denied that the money was a bribe.
